So said  Lauren Bish  on  12/15/2002 --------------------

<snip />
>What about JUnitX?

I've never used it, as I haven't found the need yet. I look forward to
other comments on it.

>While I explained why I come down on the side of testing behavior vs.
>methods explicitly, and why I think it is quite possible to test most
>private methods in that manner, I will concede that there are code or
>behavior paths that you may not be able to invoke in any other manner
- for
>example, when it comes to exceptions or errors that are just unlikely
to
>happen in normal circumstances, but for which you must create code to
>handle. It might be necessary to write explicit tests of private
methods in
>such a way as to invoke this code.

If an exceptional condition is difficult to recreate in a test, then
simply simulate it in a test. I'm assuming programmer tests, here. If
the goal is to test how the handler handles the exception, then there
are two possibilities:

(1) The CUT itself throws the exception.

In this case, you can subclass the CUT and override the method in which
the exception is thrown, then consider "Replace Subclass with
Collaborator", a refactoring which I have written up at my web site.
When it comes to testing, I find it much easier to "configure
collaborations" among classes, plugging in a "Crash Test Dummy" (see
Mike Bowler's presentation at the XP Toronto Users Group or the
Colorado Software Summit, likely at http://www.gargoylesoftware.com
somewhere) where needed to simulate the exceptional condition.

(2) Some other object throws the exception and the CUT handles it.

In this case, expose a public interface to plug in another
implementation of the exception-thrower's interface. This is simple
mocking.

I'm not sure that I understand why private methods are necessarily
involved here. There's probably some specific situation that you're
trying to address. Are you willing to (and allowed to) post code as
examples?

I hope you see good feedback on JUnitX. Sorry I couldn't give you any.
